results.title: Seeing the future
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
One of a series of films about some of the problems of forecasting, and of trying to achieve control through forecasts, particularly in the case of small and medium-sized firms. Intuition and detached statistical forecasts are both highly vulnerable to the unexpected. Unless this limitation can be overcome, forecasting is of no use to management.

results.title: Seeing It Our Way
results.brief_description: A sensitive program which gives viewers an insight into the daily lives of visually impaired people and shows how best to assist such people, especially the elderly. Simulated vision segments give viewers a true appreciation of what it is like to be visually impaired. The program covers hazards, clothes and storage, communication issues and myths, “sighted guide” techniques and more.

results.title: Seeds of violence
results.brief_description: Examines the causes of violence and destruction and shows how violence operates in a cycle which in turn stimulates retaliation and revenge. Shows how the violent urge exists in childhood as well as adulthood, focusing on bullying in the schoolground and male to female violence in teenagers - both verbal and physical abuse. Covers the topic of boredom as the reason for violent destructive behaviour. Contains some animated scenes. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Seed of success
results.creator_credit: Norman Laird and Tasmanian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Potato Seed Certification Scheme operated by the Tasmanian Department of Agriculture. Plants grown at the Tewksbury Potato Station are continuously tested for infection, and healthy seed is supplied to seed growers whose farms are inspected regularly. The certified seed which they produce carries a tag on the bag which guarantees its freedom from infection. This scheme is responsible for a rise from 2.1/2 to 4 tons per acre in Tasmania’s average yield of potatoes to the acre.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman Laird and Tasmanian Government Film Unit

results.title: Seed germination
results.creator_credit: William M. Harlow and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 2. Plant life”

Explains how seeds serve plants in reproduction, distribution and as a device to survive unfavourable climatic periods. Shows how research into seed germination aids biologists in understanding growth, development and metabolism.

results.title: Seed dispersal: seed dispersal by burial
results.brief_description: An educational documentary that examines the sowing of seeds, fertilisation and their eventual sprouting. Once sprouting has taken place the seeds are released from the grown plant.

results.title: Seed dispersal
results.brief_description: Shows ways by which seeds of various plants are scattered in order to insure the propagation of the species. The methods illustrated include dispersal by the wind, transportation by animals, and forceful propulsion from the seed-case

results.title: See. No. 5
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: 1. Modern motors replace prancing ponies - ball game with motorcycles. 2. Motor maniacs - motorcycle obstacle racing. 3. Daring daughters of destiny - women in obstacle race. 4. Lions at home - lion attending her young in a cage. 5. Wildest teamwork - lion-drawn carriage. 6. A duck? No, a lion. 7. Polite bears. 8. A cinnamon bear milk shake. 9. Jousting comes back - modern knights in armour revive medieval sport and kill. 10. Jousting - a strange sight in the peaceful Seine. 11. Angry waters - seas in a hurricane; waves lashing against ships. 12. Real scenes of a real drama - boats thrown against shore.

results.title: See, touch, feel (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Artists-in-residence at high schools in Pennsylvania, Minnesota and Colorado demonstrate and discuss their methods of teaching young people. An innovative educational program which placed contemporary artists in the schools, provides an insight into the teaching-learning process as well as into the development of creativity. Featuring artists Mac Fisher, Don Coen and Charles Huntington.
